text:
| This article **needs additional citations forverification**. Please help
improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced
material may be challenged and removed.  
_Find sources:_ "Economy of Seychelles" – news **·** newspapers **·** books
**·** scholar **·** JSTOR _( January 2025)__(Learn how and when to remove this
message)_  
---|---  
  
The **economy of Seychelles** is based on fishing, tourism, processing of
coconuts and vanilla, coir rope, boat building, printing, furniture and
beverages. Agricultural products include cinnamon, sweet potatoes, cassava
(tapioca), bananas, poultry and tuna.

The public sector, comprising the government and state-owned enterprises,
dominates the economy in terms of employment and gross revenue, employing two-
thirds of the labor force. Government consumption absorbs over one-third of
Seychelles's GDP.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Seychelles is primarily based on several key sectors including fishing, tourism, processing of coconuts and vanilla, coir rope production, boat building, printing, furniture manufacturing, and beverage production.
• Agricultural products cultivated in Seychelles include cinnamon, sweet potatoes, cassava (also known as tapioca), bananas, poultry, and tuna.
• The public sector, which consists of the government and state-owned enterprises, plays a dominant role in the Seychellois economy, particularly in terms of employment and gross revenue generation.
• Approximately two-thirds of the labor force in Seychelles are employed by the public sector.
• Government consumption accounts for over one-third of the country’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

text:
The French originally settled the Seychelles in 1770, setting up plantations
which relied heavily on slave labour to produce cotton, sugar, rice, and
maize. The British took control of the Seychelles during the Napoleonic Wars
without removing the French upper class.

After the British prohibited slavery in 1835, the influx of African workers
did not end because British warships captured Arab slavers and forced the
liberated slaves to work on plantations as apprentices without pay.

In the 1960s, about 33% of the working population worked at plantations, and
20% worked in the public or government sector.
openai_summarised_points: • The Seychelles were originally settled by the French in 1770, who established plantations that depended heavily on slave labour to cultivate cotton, sugar, rice, and maize.
• During the Napoleonic Wars, the British took control of the Seychelles but allowed the French upper class to remain in power.

• In 1835, the British abolished slavery in the Seychelles; however, the arrival of African workers continued because British warships intercepted Arab slave traders and compelled the freed slaves to work on plantations as unpaid apprentices.
• By the 1960s, approximately 33% of the Seychelles' working population was employed in plantation agriculture, while about 20% were employed in the public or government sector.

text:
| This section **does notcite any sources**. Please help improve this section
by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged
and removed. _( December 2024)__(Learn how and when to remove this message)_
---|---
Aircraft at Seychelles International Airport.

Plantations were the main industry of the Seychelles until 1971, when the
international airport opened. Overnight, tourism became a serious industry,
basically dividing the economy into plantations and tourism. The tourism
sector paid better, and the plantation economy could only expand so far.

The plantation sector of the economy declined in prominence, and tourism and
fishing became the primary industries of Seychelles. In the 1960s, about 33%
of the working population worked at plantations, but by 2006 it was less than
3%.

While the tourism and industrial fishing industries were flourishing in the
late 1990s, the traditional plantation economy atrophied. Cinnamon barks and
copra—traditional export crops—dwindled to negligible amounts by 1991. There
were no exports of copra in 1996; 318 tons of cinnamon bark was exported in
1996, reflecting a decrease of 35% in cinnamon bark exports from 1995.

The US military Indian Ocean Tracking Station on Mahé operated from 1963 until
1996.
openai_summarised_points: • Prior to 1971, plantations constituted the main industry of Seychelles, dominating the economy until the opening of the international airport that year.

• The inauguration of Seychelles International Airport in 1971 marked a pivotal shift, with tourism rapidly emerging as a serious and significant industry, effectively dividing the economy into two main sectors: plantations and tourism.
• The tourism sector offered higher wages compared to plantations, which limited the potential for further expansion of the plantation economy.
• Following the rise of tourism, the plantation sector declined in economic prominence, while tourism and fishing became the primary industries driving Seychelles’ economy.
• In the 1960s, approximately 33% of Seychelles’ working population was employed in plantations; by 2006, this figure had sharply decreased to less than 3%.
• During the late 1990s, despite the flourishing tourism and industrial fishing industries, the traditional plantation economy experienced significant atrophy.
• Traditional export crops such as cinnamon bark and copra saw drastic reductions by 1991, with copra exports ceasing entirely by 1996.
• In 1996, Seychelles exported 318 tons of cinnamon bark, representing a 35% decrease in cinnamon bark exports compared to 1995.
• The United States operated the Indian Ocean Tracking Station on Mahé island from 1963 until its closure in 1996.

text:
One of the supermarkets by the Seychelles Marketing Board, built in 1984.

Since Seychelles' independence in 1976, per capita output has expanded to
roughly seven times the old near-subsistence level.[_citation needed_] Growth
has been led by the tourist sector, which employs about 30% of the labor force
and provides more than 70% of hard currency earnings, followed by tuna
fishing.[_citation needed_] In recent years[_which?_] the government has
encouraged foreign investment in order to upgrade hotels and other
services.[_citation needed_]

At the same time, the government has moved to reduce the dependence on tourism
by promoting the development of farming, fishing, small-scale manufacturing
and most recently the offshore sector. The vulnerability of the tourist sector
was illustrated by the sharp drop in 1991-92 due largely to the Gulf
War.[_citation needed_] Although the industry has rebounded, the government
recognizes the continuing need for upgrading the sector in the face of stiff
international competition. Other issues facing the government are the curbing
of the budget deficit and further privatization of public
enterprises.[_citation needed_]

Despite attempts to improve its agricultural base and emphasize locally
manufactured products and indigenous materials, Seychelles imports 90% of the
food it consumes.[_citation needed_] The exceptions are some fruits and
vegetables, fish, poultry, pork, and beer.[_citation needed_] In addition to
that, Seychelles also produces cigarettes, paint, and a few plastic items.
Imports of all kind are controlled by the Seychelles Marketing Board (SMB), a
government parastatal which operates all the major supermarkets and is the
distributor and licensor of most other imports.[_citation needed_]

In an effort to increase agricultural self-sufficiency, Seychelles has
undertaken steps to make the sector more productive and to provide incentives
to farmers. Much of the state holdings in the agricultural sector have been
privatized, while the role of the government has been reduced to conducting
research and providing infrastructure.[_citation needed_]

In 2020, the Corruption Perception Index from Transparency International
assessed Seychelles as the least corrupt country in Africa.
openai_summarised_points: • Since gaining independence in 1976, Seychelles has experienced a significant increase in per capita output, expanding to approximately seven times the previous near-subsistence level.
• The tourism sector is the primary driver of economic growth in Seychelles, employing about 30% of the labor force and generating more than 70% of the country's hard currency earnings.
• Tuna fishing is the second most important sector contributing to Seychelles' economy after tourism.
• In recent years, the government has actively encouraged foreign investment aimed at upgrading hotels and other service industries to enhance the tourism sector.
• To reduce economic dependence on tourism, the government has promoted diversification by developing farming, fishing, small-scale manufacturing, and more recently, the offshore financial sector.
• The vulnerability of Seychelles' tourism industry was notably demonstrated by a sharp decline in tourist arrivals and earnings during 1991-1992, primarily due to the Gulf War.
• Although the tourism industry has since rebounded, the government acknowledges the ongoing necessity to upgrade the sector to remain competitive internationally.
• Key challenges facing the government include controlling the national budget deficit and advancing the privatization of public enterprises.
• Despite efforts to bolster agriculture and emphasize locally manufactured products and indigenous materials, Seychelles imports approximately 90% of its food consumption.
• The main food products produced locally include certain fruits and vegetables, fish, poultry, pork, and beer.
• Seychelles also manufactures cigarettes, paint, and a limited range of plastic items domestically.

• The Seychelles Marketing Board (SMB), a government-owned parastatal, controls all types of imports, operates all major supermarkets, and acts as the distributor and licensor for most imported goods.
• To enhance agricultural self-sufficiency, Seychelles has implemented measures to increase productivity in the sector and provide incentives to farmers.
• Much of the state's agricultural holdings have been privatized, with the government's role now primarily focused on conducting agricultural research and providing necessary infrastructure.
• In 2020, Transparency International's Corruption Perception Index ranked Seychelles as the least corrupt country in Africa.

| This section **does notcite any sources**. Please help improve this section

---|---
| This section needs to be **updated**. Please help update this article to
reflect recent events or newly available information. _( January 2025)_
---|---

Wikivoyage has a travel guide for _**Seychelles**_.

Fisherman landing his catch, in the early 1970s

Tourism is one of the most important sectors of the economy, accounting for
approximately 16.6% (2000) of GDP. Employment, foreign earnings, construction,
banking, and commerce are all dominated by tourism-related industries. Tourism
earned $631 million in 1999–2000. About 130,046 tourists visited Seychelles in
2000, 80.1% of them from Europe (United Kingdom, Italy, France, Germany, and
Switzerland).

In 2000, industrial fishing surpassed tourism as the most important foreign
exchange earner. Manufacturing, construction, and industrial fishing, notably
tuna fishing, account for about 28.8% of the GDP. Earnings are growing
annually from licensing fees paid by foreign trawlers fishing in Seychelles'
territorial waters.

In 1995, Seychelles saw the privatization of the Seychelles Tuna Canning
Factory, 60% of which was purchased by the American food company Heinz.
Similarly, some port operations have been privatized, a trend that has been
accompanied by a fall in transshipment fees and an increase in efficiency.
Overall, this has sparked a recovery in port services following a drastic fall
in 2009.
openai_summarised_points: • Tourism is a critical sector in the Seychelles economy, contributing approximately 16.6% of the GDP in the year 2000.
• The tourism industry significantly influences employment, foreign earnings, construction, banking, and commerce within Seychelles.
• In the fiscal year 1999–2000, tourism generated revenue amounting to $631 million.
• During 2000, Seychelles received about 130,046 tourists, with 80.1% originating from European countries, specifically the United Kingdom, Italy, France, Germany, and Switzerland.
• By the year 2000, industrial fishing overtook tourism as the leading source of foreign exchange earnings for Seychelles.
• Manufacturing, construction, and industrial fishing—particularly tuna fishing—collectively contributed approximately 28.8% to the GDP.
• Seychelles benefits from increasing annual earnings through licensing fees paid by foreign trawlers operating in its territorial waters.
• In 1995, the Seychelles Tuna Canning Factory underwent privatization, with 60% ownership acquired by the American food company Heinz.
• Some port operations in Seychelles have also been privatized, resulting in a reduction of transshipment fees and enhanced operational efficiency.
• The privatization and efficiency improvements in port services have led to a recovery following a significant decline in port activity in 2009.

text:
Many of the other industrial activities are limited to small scale
manufacturing, particularly agro-processing and import substitution.
Agriculture (including artisanal and forestry), once the backbone of the
economy, now accounts for around 3% of the GDP.
openai_summarised_points: • Many industrial activities in Seychelles are confined to small-scale manufacturing, with a particular focus on agro-processing and import substitution.

• Agriculture, encompassing artisanal practices and forestry, was historically the backbone of the Seychelles economy but currently contributes approximately 3% to the nation's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

| This section **does notcite any sources**. Please help improve this section

---|---

The public sector, comprising the government and state-owned enterprises,
dominates the economy in terms of employment and gross revenue, employing two-
thirds of the labor force. Public consumption absorbs over one-third of the
GDP.
openai_summarised_points: • The public sector in Seychelles includes both the government and state-owned enterprises, collectively dominating the national economy in terms of employment and gross revenue.
• Approximately two-thirds of the Seychelles labor force are employed within the public sector, highlighting its significant role as the primary employer in the country.
• Public consumption in Seychelles accounts for over one-third of the gross domestic product (GDP), indicating a substantial portion of economic activity is driven by government spending.
• This dominance of the public sector underscores its critical influence on Seychelles' economic structure and labor market dynamics.

text:
| This section **does notcite any sources**. Please help improve this section
by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged
and removed. _( January 2025)__(Learn how and when to remove this message)_
---|---

The Seychelles economy is extremely vulnerable to external shocks. Not only
does it depend on tourism, but it imports over 90% of its total primary and
secondary production inputs. Any decline in tourism quickly translates into a
fall in GDP, a decline in foreign exchange receipts, and budgetary
difficulties.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Seychelles is highly susceptible to external shocks, indicating a fragile economic structure.
• Seychelles' economic dependence on tourism is significant, making the sector a critical driver of national income.
• The country imports over 90% of its total primary and secondary production inputs, highlighting a heavy reliance on foreign goods and materials.
• A decrease in tourism activity rapidly leads to a reduction in the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Declines in tourism also cause a drop in foreign exchange earnings, which are vital for the country's economic stability.
• Reduced foreign exchange receipts subsequently result in budgetary challenges for the government of Seychelles.
• The section currently lacks cited sources and has a notice requesting the addition of reliable references as of January 2025.

text:
Growth slowed in 1998–2001, due to sluggish tourist and tuna sectors. Also,
tight controls on exchange rates and the scarcity of foreign exchange have
impaired short-term economic prospects. The black market value of the
Seychellois rupee is anywhere from two thirds to one half the official
exchange rate.[_citation needed_] The next few years were also slow due to the
worldwide economic downturn and the fear of flying brought on by the terrorism
on 11 September 2001.

More recently though, tourism has roared back at a record pace setting
successive records in 2006 and again in 2007 for number of visitors.[_citation
needed_] The increased availability of flights to and from the archipelago due
in part to new entrants Emirates and Qatar airlines is also beginning to show.
Both at official exchange rates and at purchasing power parity (PPP),
Seychelles remains the richest territory in Africa in terms of GDP per capita
(US$9,440.095 at real exchange rates and US$17,560.062 at PPP 2008 estimate),

Because of economic contraction (the economy declined by about 2% in 2004 and
2005 and lost another 1.4% in 2006 according to the International Monetary
Fund) the country was moving downwards in terms of per capita income. However,
the economy bounced back in 2007, growing by 5.3% due in part to record
tourism numbers and the booming building and offshore industries. The IMF
forecast further growth in 2008 with continuing increase in the GDP per
capita.

In October 2008, as tourism and fishing revenue began slowing, the Seychelles
defaulted on a $230 million debt. The International Monetary Fund stepped with
a two-year, $26 million rescue package. The rescue package came with a few
stipulations; The country laid off 1,800 government workers, floated its
currency, lifted foreign exchange controls and sold off state assets. At the
time, the country's $800 million external foreign debt was equivalent to
almost 175 percent of its gross domestic product.

The decision to let the currency trade freely as part of the IMF rescue
package means that Seychelles is the smallest country in the world that has a
completely independent currency - one that is neither pegged, nor an adopted
foreign currency, nor a common currency used within a larger monetary union.
When the Seychellois rupee became freely floated on 3 November 2008, its value
quickly fell drastically, decreasing from eight per U.S. dollar to 16,
effectively doubled the prices of imports.

The global recession and piracy in the Indian Ocean hit Seychelles hard in
2009, with the GDP projected to contract by 7.5 percent. However the
government exceeded its fiscal targets, with a primary surplus of 13.4% of GDP
in the first nine months of 2009 according to the IMF. They report expenditure
has been tightly controlled and revenue has held up well despite the difficult
economic environment.

In May 2010 an International Monetary Fund mission visited Seychelles and
concluded the country is making progress. The head of the mission, Mr. Jean Le
Dem, said at the conclusion of the visit:

> The economy is recovering from a recession that put real gross domestic
> product (GDP) to almost a stand in 2009. Real GDP is projected to grow at 4
> percent in 2010, reflecting primarily a rebound in tourism earnings. Twelve-
> month inflation, which was negative during the past few months, is expected
> to return to about 1 percent by year-end

In 2017 the Seychelles joined the World Trade Organisation, facilitated by
Omani economist Hilda al-Hinai, who chaired the Working Group.
openai_summarised_points: • Economic growth in Seychelles slowed between 1998 and 2001 due to sluggish performance in the tourism and tuna sectors, compounded by tight exchange rate controls and a scarcity of foreign exchange, which impaired short-term economic prospects.
• During this period, the black market value of the Seychellois rupee ranged from two thirds to one half of the official exchange rate, reflecting significant currency valuation disparities.
• The global economic downturn and the fear of flying following the terrorist attacks on 11 September 2001 further contributed to the slow economic growth in the early 2000s.

• Tourism experienced a strong recovery in the mid-2000s, setting successive visitor number records in 2006 and again in 2007, aided by increased flight availability from new airline entrants such as Emirates and Qatar Airways.

• Seychelles maintained its status as the richest territory in Africa by GDP per capita in 2008, with estimates of US$9,440.095 at real exchange rates and US$17,560.062 at purchasing power parity (PPP).

• Despite this wealth, the economy contracted by approximately 2% in both 2004 and 2005, and by an additional 1.4% in 2006, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), causing a decline in per capita income.

• The economy rebounded in 2007 with a 5.3% growth rate, driven by record tourism numbers and growth in the building and offshore industries, with the IMF forecasting continued GDP per capita increases in 2008.
• In October 2008, as tourism and fishing revenues began to slow, Seychelles defaulted on a $230 million debt, prompting the IMF to provide a two-year, $26 million rescue package.

• The IMF rescue package required Seychelles to implement austerity measures including laying off 1,800 government workers, floating its currency, lifting foreign exchange controls, and selling off state assets.
• At the time of the bailout, Seychelles’ external foreign debt stood at $800 million, equivalent to almost 175% of its gross domestic product, highlighting severe debt distress.

• The decision to float the Seychellois rupee on 3 November 2008 made Seychelles the smallest country in the world with a fully independent currency that is neither pegged, adopted, nor part of a monetary union.
• Following the currency float, the Seychellois rupee’s value dropped sharply from 8 to 16 per U.S. dollar, effectively doubling the cost of imports and impacting domestic prices.

• The global recession and increased piracy in the Indian Ocean severely affected Seychelles in 2009, with GDP projected to contract by 7.5%, yet the government achieved a primary fiscal surplus of 13.4% of GDP in the first nine months of 2009 through tight expenditure control and resilient revenue collection, as reported by the IMF.

• An IMF mission in May 2010, led by Mr. Jean Le Dem, concluded that Seychelles was making economic progress, projecting a 4% real GDP growth in 2010 driven primarily by a rebound in tourism earnings, with inflation expected to return to about 1% by year-end after a period of negative inflation.
• In 2017, Seychelles joined the World Trade Organization (WTO), a process facilitated by Omani economist Hilda al-Hinai, who chaired the WTO Working Group overseeing the accession.

text:
| This section **does notcite any sources**. Please help improve this section
by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged
and removed. _( December 2024)__(Learn how and when to remove this message)_
---|---

In addition to the now booming tourism and building/real estate markets,
Seychelles has renewed its commitment to developing its financial services
sector. Government officials and industry participants believe this could
overtake the tourism industry as the chief pillar of the economy by 2017. The
recent passage of a revised Mutual Fund Act 2007, Securities Act 2007 and
Insurance Act 2007 are meant to be the catalysts to move Seychelles from just
another offshore jurisdiction to a full-fledged Offshore Financial Center
(OFC).

The Ministry of Finance is responsible for economic decisions and budgetary
policy. A separate Monetary Authority supervises the banking system and
manages the money supply. Although foreign banks operate branches in
Seychelles, the government owns the two local banks—the Development Bank of
Seychelles, which mobilizes resources to fund development programs, and the
Seychelles Saving Bank, a bank for savings and current accounts.

The Financial Services Authority (formerly Seychelles International Business
Authority - SIBA) is charged with overseeing the quickly growing non-banking
financial services industry.
openai_summarised_points: • Seychelles has renewed its commitment to developing its financial services sector alongside its booming tourism and building/real estate markets, with government officials and industry participants anticipating that financial services could surpass tourism as the chief pillar of the economy by 2017.

• The passage of key legislation in 2007, including the revised Mutual Fund Act 2007, Securities Act 2007, and Insurance Act 2007, was intended to transform Seychelles from a typical offshore jurisdiction into a full-fledged Offshore Financial Center (OFC).
• The Ministry of Finance in Seychelles is responsible for making economic decisions and formulating budgetary policy for the country.
• A separate Monetary Authority supervises the banking system and manages the money supply within Seychelles.

• Although foreign banks operate branches in Seychelles, the government owns the two local banks: the Development Bank of Seychelles, which mobilizes resources to fund development programs, and the Seychelles Saving Bank, which provides savings and current account services.

• The Financial Services Authority, formerly known as the Seychelles International Business Authority (SIBA), is tasked with overseeing the rapidly growing non-banking financial services industry in Seychelles.

text:
New detailed studies and exploration shows that the Seychelles potentially
have large off-shore petroleum reservoirs which are yet to be discovered.
Drills have proven the presence of:

1. Oil-prone source rocks containing Type II kerogen in coaly deltaic shales of the Middle Jurassic and in marine shales of the Upper Jurassic;
2. Mixed source rocks bearing Type II/III kerogen in deltaic marine shales of the Lower Cretaceous that are II correlative of oil-generating shales in Somalia;
3. Gas-prone sources containing Type I kerogen in Upper Triassic fluvial shales and Paleocene marine shales, the latter being correlative of oil and gas generating source rocks of the Deep Continental Shelf trend of the Bombay High Oil Province offshore west India;
4. Evidence of hydrocarbon generation and migration with well shows, such as 0.7 ml benzene in DST-1 of Reith Bank-1, 10,010 ppm of 99.8% n-C4 headspace gas coincident with as small fault in the same well and 20% petrol vapours at an immature level of volcanics in Owen Bank A-1;
5. Clastic reservoirs with measured porosities up to 22% in the Early-Middle Jurassic;
6. Sealing lithologies occur both locally in syn-rift, and regionally in post-rift sequences;
7. An extensive seismic dataset, plus a variety of remote sensing data have been collected which bolster the well data by confirming the presence of:
8. A variety of trapping styles, dominated by tilted fault blocks, stratigraphic pinchouts and reefs;
9. Multiple heating events, with the principal event post-dating trap formation; and
10. Hydrocarbon generation and migration with the presence of: a) numerous DHIs on seismic, including gas chimneys, flat spots, bright spots, phase changes and chemosynthetic reefs; b) gas sniffer anomalies, involving ethane/iso-butane in the southeast and propane/normal butane/total hydrocarbon in the north and northeast; c) UV fluorescence anomalies, especially over the wells and in the southeast; and d) 4 types of beach-stranded tar that correlate to the local source rock stratigraphy.

However, to date all exploratory and stratigraphic test wells (a total of 9
since the 1970s) in the Seychelles have failed to find commercial
hydrocarbons. The most recent wildcat by Enterprise Oil in 1995 detected gas
but failed to find hydrocarbons.

Several oil and gas exploration companies are active in the Seychelles
offshore. These include East African Exploration (EAX) (a subsidiary of
Afren), Avana Petroleum (a subsidiary of Vanoil Energy) and WHL Energy.

Beginning at the turn of the millennium the Seychelles Petroleum Company
(SEPEC) started to develop the first fleet of modern petroleum double-hull
tankers, with five vessels, which was completed by late 2007/early 2008 with
the possibility to build more in the near future. The Seychelles President
claims that this has opened the door to a new industry for his country and
encouraged economic growth by further removing over-reliance on traditional
trades like fisheries and tourism, which is now falling rapidly as the
country's main income but nevertheless, has experienced significant growth in
recent years.

The country has also increased its capacity for wind power, with windfarms on
Romainville Island.
openai_summarised_points: • Recent detailed studies and exploration indicate that Seychelles potentially possesses large offshore petroleum reservoirs that remain undiscovered.
• Drilling results have confirmed the presence of oil-prone source rocks containing Type II kerogen in coaly deltaic shales of the Middle Jurassic and marine shales of the Upper Jurassic.
• Mixed source rocks bearing Type II/III kerogen have been identified in deltaic marine shales of the Lower Cretaceous, which are correlative with oil-generating shales found in Somalia.

• Gas-prone sources containing Type I kerogen exist in Upper Triassic fluvial shales and Paleocene marine shales; the latter correlates with oil and gas generating source rocks of the Deep Continental Shelf trend of the Bombay High Oil Province offshore west India.

• Evidence of hydrocarbon generation and migration includes well shows such as 0.7 ml benzene detected in DST-1 of Reith Bank-1, 10,010 ppm of 99.8% n-C4 headspace gas coinciding with a small fault in the same well, and 20% petrol vapors at an immature volcanic level in Owen Bank A-1.
• Clastic reservoirs with measured porosities up to 22% have been found in the Early-Middle Jurassic formations.
• Sealing lithologies are present both locally in syn-rift sequences and regionally in post-rift sequences, providing potential hydrocarbon traps.

• An extensive seismic dataset and various remote sensing data have been collected, supporting well data by confirming the presence of multiple geological features relevant to hydrocarbon exploration.
• Identified trapping styles are diverse, dominated by tilted fault blocks, stratigraphic pinchouts, and reefs.
• Multiple heating events have occurred, with the principal heating event post-dating the formation of traps, facilitating hydrocarbon maturation.

• Hydrocarbon generation and migration evidence includes: a) numerous Direct Hydrocarbon Indicators (DHIs) on seismic data such as gas chimneys, flat spots, bright spots, phase changes, and chemosynthetic reefs; b) gas sniffer anomalies involving ethane/iso-butane in the southeast and propane/normal butane/total hydrocarbons in the north and northeast; c) ultraviolet fluorescence anomalies, particularly over wells and in the southeast; and d) four types of beach-stranded tar correlating with local source rock stratigraphy.

• Despite these promising geological indicators, all exploratory and stratigraphic test wells drilled in Seychelles since the 1970s—a total of nine wells—have failed to discover commercial hydrocarbons.
• The most recent wildcat well drilled by Enterprise Oil in 1995 detected gas but did not find commercial hydrocarbons.

• Several oil and gas exploration companies are currently active offshore Seychelles, including East African Exploration (EAX), a subsidiary of Afren; Avana Petroleum, a subsidiary of Vanoil Energy; and WHL Energy.

• Starting around the year 2000, the Seychelles Petroleum Company (SEPEC) initiated the development of the first fleet of modern petroleum double-hull tankers, comprising five vessels completed by late 2007 or early 2008, with potential plans for further expansion.

• The President of Seychelles has stated that the development of this tanker fleet has opened new industrial opportunities for the country, encouraging economic growth and reducing over-reliance on traditional sectors such as fisheries and tourism.
• Although tourism remains a significant income source, its relative contribution has been declining, while the economy has experienced notable growth in recent years.
• Seychelles has also expanded its renewable energy capacity, notably through the establishment of wind farms on Romainville Island.

openai_summarised_points: • The official exchange rate GDP of Seychelles was $1.498 billion in 2017, while the GDP based on purchasing power parity (PPP) was $2.75 billion in the same year.
• Seychelles experienced a real GDP growth rate of +5.3% in 2017, an increase from 0.8% in 2016.
• The GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity was $29,300 in 2017.
• The GDP composition by sector in 2017 was as follows: agriculture accounted for 2.5%, industry for 13.8%, and services dominated with 83.7%.
• The inflation rate based on consumer prices was 2.9% in 2017, showing a rise from -1% in 2016.
• The labor force in Seychelles was estimated at 47,210 individuals in 2017.
• Labor force distribution by occupation in 2006 was 74% in services, 23% in industry, and 3% in agriculture.
• The unemployment rate was estimated at 3% in 2017.
• The government budget in 2017 showed revenues of $593.4 million and expenditures of $600.7 million.

• Key industries in Seychelles include fishing, tourism, processing of coconuts and vanilla, production of coir (coconut fiber), rope manufacturing, boat building, printing, furniture making, and beverage production.
• The industrial production growth rate was 2.3% in 2017.
• Major agricultural products include coconuts, cinnamon, vanilla, sweet potatoes, cassava (tapioca), bananas, poultry, and tuna.
• Total exports were valued at $564.8 million in 2017.
• Export commodities primarily consist of canned tuna, frozen fish, and petroleum products (re-exports).
• As of 2013, the main export products were processed fish (60%) and non-fillet frozen fish (22%).
• The main export partners in 2017 were the United Arab Emirates (28.5%), France (24%), the United Kingdom (13.5%), Italy (8.9%), and Germany (4.6%).
• Historical export partners in 2004 included the UK (27.6%), France (15.8%), Spain (12.7%), Japan (8.6%), Italy (7.5%), and Germany (5.6%).
• Imports totaled $1.155 billion in 2017, up from $991 million in 2016.
• Import commodities include machinery and equipment, foodstuffs, petroleum products, chemicals, and other manufactured goods.
• Major import partners in 2017 were the United Arab Emirates (13.4%), France (9.4%), Spain (5.7%), and South Africa (5%).
• Seychelles' external debt was $2.559 billion as of 31 December 2017, slightly down from $2.651 billion on 31 December 2016.
• The currency of Seychelles is the Seychelles rupee (SCR or SRe), subdivided into 100 cents.

• Exchange rates of Seychelles rupees per US dollar were 13.64 in 2017, 13.319 in 2015, 12.747 in 2013, 11.85 in May 2010, 16.7 in February 2009, 8.0 in 2008, 5.8 in 2007, 5.5 in 2006, 5.3 in 1999, and 4.7 in 1995.
• Exchange rates of Seychelles rupees per Pound Sterling were 17.50 in May 2010 and 24.11 in February 2009.
• Exchange rates of Seychelles rupees per Euro were 15.04 in May 2010 and 21.55 in February 2009.
• The fiscal year in Seychelles follows the calendar year.
